Bee Time

spent studying these creatures, and on the 
lessons they can teach about how humans 
might better interact with one another and 
the natural world.

This seems to be a form of

own

Why would any insect give up its own 
reproduction in order to rear offspring for the 
queen?

Eusociality was puzzling 
for Charles Darwin 
“But with the working ant we have an insect differing 
greatly from its parents, yet absolutely sterile; so that 
it could never have transmitted successively acquired 
modifications of structure or instinct to its progeny.
It may well be asked how is it possible to reconcile this 
case with the theory of natural selection?”

Part 2. The concept of Kin selection and how it can 
explain eusociality

Answer
: There can be advantages to rearing another 
insects’ offspring when you are genetically related to that 
other individual, and when founding your own nest 
instead is a risky proposition. 
Hamilton’s kin selection theory 
William 
Hamilton

Hamilton’s kin selection theory
: 
Inclusive fitness = direct fitness + indirect fitness 
Direct fitness 
– 
Genes passed on to the next 
generation via ones’ own offspring 
Indirect fitness 
– 
Genes passed on to the next 
generation via relatives 
Inclusive fitness 
– 
The 
overall
 
evolutionary 
“fitness” of an organism, measured by the amount 
of its genetic material being passed to the next 
generation either 
directly
 
or 
indirectly
.

•
 
Natural selection favors altruism when 
rB 
> C 
r = relatedness between altruist and recipient 
B = fitness benefit to recipient 
C = fitness cost to the altruist 
•
 
This inequality is called 
Hamilton’s rule

One important caveat: 
honey bee queens 
mate with 
an average of 12 drones thus worker sisters can have 
a different father! 
• 
How is that fact influencing the Relatedness (r) between worker 
sisters since they are not full siblings? 
• 
Super sisters share the same drone as a “father” and are 75% 
similar 
• 
Others have different fathers and are half sisters thus sharing 
25% of their genes. 
• 
Relatedness is anywhere between 0.25 and 0.75, depending on 
which sperm was used, and how genetically different the drones 
were.

Part 3. Division of labor in honey bee colonies

TWO forms of Division of Labor in honeybees 
1) 
Reproductive castes 
• 
Queens vs. workers vs. drones 
2) 
Behavioral castes 
• 
Task specialization among workers 
• 
Temporal 
polyethism
* 
*
Polyethism
::the differentiation of behavior among 
categories of individuals within the society, 
especially age and sex classes and castes.

Temporal Polyethism in workers 
Honey bees have an elaborate DOL in which worker tasks are divided, 
by age, resulting in highly efficient colony organization 
Older ones forage 
outside 
younger ones clean, 
nurse, etc inside

There is variation for the age 
at which a task starts 
Very flexible 
system:
Develop earlier 
if needed or 
revert back if 
needed

Bees work serially rather than by multitasking, an 
aspect of labor that provides an effective 
combination of specialized task performance and 
the flexibility to allocate the workforce where it's 
needed. 
How can this possibly be controlled?

What are the proximate mechanisms 
of temporal poly
e
thism
? 
• 
DOL in 
honey bees 
results from an intricate interplay of genetic, 
hormonal, neural, and environmental factors. This ensures 
flexibility and resilience in the colony's functioning, allowing it to 
adapt to changing internal and external conditions. 
• 
W
orker bees do not 
“know” when to switch 
f
rom one job to 
another 
(they do not have a conscious awareness). Rather, each 
bee’s response is dependent upon its sensibility to stimuli 
coming from other bees and from the hive... 
35

A 
few 
examples of factors that play a role in 
regulating DOL in honey bees 
• 
Hormonal Regulation
: Levels of JH (Juvenile hormone) influence the transition 
from in
-
hive tasks (like nursing) to outside tasks (like foraging). Young bees have 
low JH levels, which rise as they age, promoting the shift to foraging. 
• 
Genetic Predisposition
: Different worker bees may have slight genetic variations 
influencing their likelihood to take on certain roles. Some bees might be more 
genetically inclined to become foragers, while others might be more predisposed 
to nursing. 
• 
Environmental Feedback
: Bees can adjust their roles in response to 
environmental cues. 
• 
If there's a sudden influx of nectar, more bees might become foragers to 
exploit the resource. 
• 
If many foragers are lost, younger bees might start foraging earlier than usual. 
• 
Variations in temperature, humidity, and other external factors can influence 
tasks like fanning or water collection.

Division of labor is highly beneficial for honey bees 
– 
Improved society functioning: all jobs get done 
– 
Improved performance by specialization 
• 
Evolved morphological or behavioral specializations 
• 
Learned specializations 
– 
Allows for an increasingly large and complex social system

Part 4. Why is the honey bee called a 
superorganism?

In what way is the honey bee society a 
superorganism? 
•
 
Just like a body has 
specialized reproductive cells, 
called gonads, a honey bee 
colony has a specialized
reproductive individual 
(queen). 
•
 
The rest of the cells, called 
somatic cells, cannot 
reproduce and neither can the

acid

Honey bee workers are also
specialized
